Danys tiene 26 años de edad, el siempre se ha dedicado al comercio de productos posee una experiencia de ocho años en dicha actividad, ya que desde muy joven se quedo viviendo solo, porque su madre se fue a Estados Unidos por el deseo de superación económica para la familia, dichas circunstancias han hecho de Danys un hombre responsable y trabajador, actualmente se ha dedicado a vender perfumes, aunque su inventario es muy escaso, es por eso que solicita de un crédito para invertir en mercadería para salir a vender de manera ambulante.
texts.en:
Danys Edgardo M. C., originally from the Department of La Libertad, El Salvador, lives with his wife and his 6 month-old son. Danys is 26 years old and has always been dedicated to the business of selling products. He has 8 years of experience in this activity since he has lived alone since he was very young because his mother went to the U.S. because of her desire to help improve her family's economic situation. These circumstances have made Danys a responsible and hard-working man. Currently he works selling perfumes, although his inventory is low. That is why he requests a credit in order to invest in merchandise that he will sell as a walking salesman.

Translated from Spanish by Seton Hill University , Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase merchandise to resell

loans.name: Lilia Flor

texts.es:
La señora Lilia Flor, pertenece al Banco Comunal “Mujeres Luchadoras”, Distrito de Tarapoto, Provincia de San Martín, Departamento de San Martín. Es Casada, tiene 45 años y es madre de 02 hijos, que aun dependen de ella.

Lilia Flor, se dedica a la venta de queso,  hace 4 años atrás y nos cuenta que se iniciaron juntamente con su esposo con un capital de S/. 100.00 y trabajaban con pedidos anticipados de sus clientes. Actualmente, se encuentra mas establecida y cuentan con un fundo donde crían sus propios ganados vacunos y a diario extraen la leche de sus vacas, para la preparación de los quesos, y cuentan  con un ambiente muy bien acondicionado. 

Con este préstamo de S/. 1000.00, lo invertirá comprando insumos como: cuajos de leche, limón en kilos, sal y algunos moldes para sus quesos y tercios de leña. 

Lilia Flor, se siente muy satisfecha con el trabajo que realiza, pese que es un trabajo duro,  cree que vale el sacrificio para cumplir sus sueños y metas que tiene trazado en su vida. Así mismo agradece al Movimiento Manuela Ramos por brindarle apoyo a ella y a  las demás mujeres que quieren salir adelante y brindarle una vejez tranquila.
texts.en:
Lilia Flor belongs to the Mujeres Luchadoras Communal Bank in the Tarapoto district, San Martín province, San Martín department. She is 45, married, and has two dependent children. Lilia Flor sells cheese. She tells us that four years ago she began with her husband and 100 PEN. They worked on anticipated orders from her customers. She is currently better established. They have a farm where they raise their own cows. They milk the cows daily in order to makes the cheeses. They have a well equipped place. She will use this loan for 1,000 PEN to buy supplies like milk rennet, kilos of lemons, salt, some molds for her cheeses, and firewood. Lilia Flor feels very satisfied with the work that she does. It is hard work, but she believes it is worth the sacrifice to fulfill her dreams and meet the goals she has outlined for her life. She is grateful to the Movimiento Manuela Ramos for offering support to her and to the rest of the women who want to get ahead and have a peaceful old age

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy supplies for makes cheese

loans.name: Uuganbayar

texts.en:
Uuganbayar is 41 years old and lives with her husband and three children in the Khovd province of western Mongolia. She and her family live in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. Her daughter, 20, attends university and her two sons, 14 and 12, both attend a local secondary school. Uuganbayar operates a home goods retail business in two shipping containers at her local market. She began her business in 2000 in a rented stall at the market and over the years, her business has grown and become successful. In the near future, she would like to purchase one more shipping container so that she can expand her business even further and grow her customer base. Uuganbayar is requesting a 2,300,000 tugrug (~1620 USD) loan in order to purchase more home goods such as pots, pans, silverware, dishes, etc. for her growing business.

About XacBank XacBank was founded in 2001, and listed its first loan on Kiva in January 2009. It is the largest microfinance organization in Mongolia, but also has mainstream commercial operations. XacBank has the vision, scale and innovation to develop and implement new solutions to poverty. It is currently utilizing Kiva’s 0% lending interest rate to return 9% of interest paid from borrowers to them in the form of a savings account at the end of their loans. This not only allows borrowers to gain financially, but also encourages them to save. To get regular updates from XacBank, please join our lending team: http://www.kiva.org/team/xacbank_mongolia

loans.use: To purchase more home goods such as pots, pans, silverware, dishes

loans.name: Julieta

texts.en:
Julieta L. is from the village of Yumbing, Mambajao Camiguin Province. She is 47 years old and widowed with six school-age children. To make a living, Julieta owns and operates a specialized retail business, selling a variety of personal products in the local community. Julieta has been engaged in her business for more than six years and earns approximately 3,500 PHP a month.

In 2009, Julieta joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Julieta is requesting a loan of 4,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Julieta from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Christina

texts.en:
Christina T. is 34 and married with 3 children (ages 1-month - 8).  She owns a business venture, selling pancakes (fried flour pancakes flavored with lemon or coconut jam).  Christina has 1 year of experience in this business.  Christina needs a loan of WST $1000 to buy flour, flavoring, sugar, and plastic bags.  She plans to use the earnings from her business (estimated to be 300 talas or US $125 per week) to improve/expand the business.

In 2009, Christina joined SPBD.  This is her 1st loan with SPBD. SPBD's loans are Christina's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with traditional banks.

The following social metrics for Christina T. are provided by SPBD*:
Overall Social Metric Score:                1.87 out of 3
Level of Education:                              2 out of 3
Level of total Household Income:         2 out of 3
Quality of Household Assets:              2 out of 3

*SPBD measures the living conditions of each of its borrowers to track her loan progress. The overall social metric score, provided by SPBD, is based upon a number of factors, such as the condition of the house/household assets, health, education, income level, and family reputation. A higher number represents a higher score. For example, a ""3 out of 3"" on education would mean that the borrower has graduated from university; a ""2 out of 3"" = secondary/high-school, and a ""1 out of 3"" would mean that the borrower is uneducated.

For more information on this score, please see SPBD's partner page at: http://partners.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=15

About SPBD
In 2000, Greg Casagrande founded SPBD and since then, it has expanded from the main island of Upolu in Samoa to Savaii, as well as Tonga. SPBD's philosophy of lending is based upon the Grameen Bank lending method.

Please join SPBD's lending team on KIVA to receive on-the-spot updates on SPBD: http://www.kiva.org/community/viewTeam?team_id=8375

loans.use: to buy flour, flavoring, sugar, and plastic bags

loans.name: Jovelyn

texts.en:
Jovelyn S. is from the village of Guinsiliban, Camiguin Province. She is 21 years-old and married with one baby. Jovelyn owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling food and daily use products in the local community. Jovelyn is just starting this business.

In 2009, Jovelyn joined Kiva partner HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Jovelyn is requesting a first loan of 4,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in the business.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy more lace clothes, slippers and jewelry to sell

loans.name: Marjorie

texts.en:
Marjorie P. is from the village of Lapinig, Kapatagan, Lanao Del Norte. She is 27 years old. Marjorie is married and has 3 children. To make a living, Marjorie owns & operates a specialized retail store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling seafood products, including fish and shrimp, in the local community. Marjorie has been engaged in her business for over 4 years and earns approximately 3000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Marjorie joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Marjorie has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from GDMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Marjorie is requesting a new loan of 7000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be the second loan taken out by Marjorie from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to invest in expanding the business

loans.name: George

texts.en: George is 28 years old and married with one child who attends school.  He has been in the welding business for six years; he makes metal doors, gates, windows and does general welding.  He earns extra income from a tailoring business.  He dreams of owning plots of land and building residential and commercial houses.  He also dreams of owning a vehicle and a motorcycle in future.  He has requested a loan of Kes. 20,000 to buy a mill for grinding grain and purchase welding materials.  He describes himself as hard-working.

loans.use: Buy a mill for grinding grain and welding materials

loans.name: Sohibjon

texts.en:
M. Sohibjon is 41 years old, married, and has two children. He sells cattle and, as a rule, purchases small cattle in the central market, feeds them, and than resells them at higher prices in the local market. Having been in this business for ten years, Sohibjon knows very well how to choose the animals, breed them and look after them. He gets up early every morning in order to feed the animals and look after them. His knowledge and skills allow him to make his business successful and generate a stable and considerable income for his large family. Sohibjon has a large and friendly family who are always trying to help each other.
Today, knowing that prices for animals are not so high now, but will increase for sure, Sohibjon is planning to enlarge his stock and purchase cattle. With this purpose in mind, he is requesting $1000 USD. You could become an important part of Sohibjon's family's life. He deeply appreciates the trust and support you are giving him.

More about Tajikistan
Tajikistan, a key post on the Silk Road, is perhaps best known for its rich history. It was the location for the end of Alexander the Great's rule, and is known for its great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets such as Rudaki, Ibn Sina (Avicenna), Firdousi, Omar Haiyam, Jomi, Mavlavi Rumi and many others. The country, with its epic mountain passes, is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language and a civilization that dates back to the fourth millennium BC. Even today, it is a complex mix of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.
However, Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the USSR, damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93 per cent of the country is mountainous and only 7 per cent of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands of people to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

More about IMON International
Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low-income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To purchase cattle to expand his business

loans.name: Zoila Esperanza

texts.es: Zoila Esperanza A. O. de 48 años de edad, reside en el municipio de Santa María, ubicado en el departamento de Usulután. Vive junto a su esposo, quien se dedica a trabajar. Zoila posee una panadería la cual esta ubicada en su propio hogar, en donde ella junto a dos personas más se encarga de elaborar el pan, el cual es horneado en un horno artesanal en el cual se cocina el pan con fuego producido por leña, lo cual es muy llamativo para diferentes personas, ya que este oficio de esta manera es muy escaso en la actualidad. Zoila sale a repartir el pan con los diferentes clientes los cuales la consideran una persona muy trabajadora y responsable quien siempre entrega sus pedidos a tiempo, por lo que muchas personas la prefieren. Zoila solicita un préstamo a Integral, por medio del cual pueda contar con el dinero necesario para invertir en el negocio comprando toda la materia prima necesaria para la elaboración del pan, tales como harina, levadura, azúcar y otros más, así mismo poder comprar mayor cantidad de leña para obtenerla a precios más bajos. La panadería para Zoila ha resultado ser un negocio muy factible, el cual no solo le permite salir adelante como persona sino también salir adelante con su hogar.
texts.en:
Zoila is 48 years old and lives in Santa María, located in the Usultán department. She lives with her husband who works. Zoila has a bakery in her home, where she and two other people bake bread in a wood fired artesian oven. This attracts many people because this method of baking is very uncommon now. Zoila delivers the bread to different customers who consider her to be a hard working and responsible person. Many people prefer to buy from her because she always delivers on time. She is asking for this loan through Integral in order to invest in her business and buy ingredients and supplies such as flour, yeast, sugar, etc. She would also like to buy a large quantity of firewood in order to be able to buy at lower prices. They bakery has proven to be a successful business, not only allowing her to get ahead as a person, but also within her home.

Translated from Spanish by Hugo Reyes, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Ingredients and firewood

loans.name: Luis Alberto

texts.es: El Sr. Luis Alberto A. J. vive en el Caserío de Fuerza Armada, perteneciente al distrito de Santiago, junto a su esposa y a su hijo. Trabaja como obrero de campo en empresas agricolas de la zona. Tiene casa propia en el caserio de San Antonio y solicita financiamiento para continuar con la construcción  de su vivienda. Su sueño es poder brindar una mejor calidad de vida a su familia. El Sr. Luis Alberto A. J. agradece el apoyo que le podamos brindar a atravez de este financiamiento.
texts.en:
Luis Alberto A. J. lives in the hamlet of Fuerza Armada, belonging to the district of Santiago, along with his wife and son. He works as a laborer at an agricultural enterprise in that zone. He has his own house in San Antonio, and seeks financing to continue building it. His dream is to provide a higher standard of living for his family. Mr. J. appreciates the support that we can provide for him through this loan.

Translated from Spanish by Mary Lynn Malaby, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To make improvements to his home.

loans.name: Vanny

texts.en:
Mrs. Vanny S. lives in Tuol Kandal village in Takeo province. She was born in 1971. She is a farmer who owns a 2.4-hectare plot of land where she cultivates rice to sell to support the family. Her husband, Mr. Cham Roeun Orem, is a fisherman and is shown in the photo with her. This couple does not have any children.

Her problem is that her field has infertile soil, it is a long way from an irrigation system and it has a lot of insects. So, to improve rice production, Mrs. Vanny S. is seeking a loan to buy fertilizer, pesticide, and to hire farming laborers to plow the rice field.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer, pesticide, and to hire laborers to plow the field

loans.name: Men

texts.en:
Men V., 23, is married and resides with her husband and a young child in Kampong Chnang Province, Cambodia, an area known for clay and ceramic products. She is employed at a garment factory for an income of about $2.60 per day. Her husband is a motor-taxi driver, earning an income of $4 per day to help cover the family's expenses.  

V. is requesting a loan of $700 to repair her house. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to open a clothes shop. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To repair her house

loans.name: Marieta

texts.en:
Marieta M. is from the village of Brgy Buliwao, Quezon, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 38 years old and married with three small children. To make a living, Marieta has a retail store selling AVON and MSE (Marikina Shoe Exchange) products. She has been engaged in her business for over 8 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month.

In 2008, Marieta joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Marieta has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Marieta is requesting a new loan of 6000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items to expand her product offering. This will be the fourth loan taken out by Marieta from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase new items to expand product offering

loans.name: Agnes

texts.en:
Agnes A. operates a provisions shop at Abura.  Agnes has received senior high education.  She is married and has two children. Her husband is a driver. 

Agnes has been in this business for five years. She helps her husband in the payment of school fees and utility bills. Her loan will be used to buy more provisions for sale. She hopes to use the fresh profits from her business to save to buy a piece of land.

loans.use: to buy more provisions for sale

loans.name: Eliabeth

texts.en: Eliabeth P. sells different types of women dresses, head dresses, necklaces, and earring at her shop. She is requesting a loan to stock bedsheets and women sandles to sell.  Eliabeth is 35 years old and married to a head teacher. She has 3 children who all attend school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house for renting.

loans.use: To stock bedsheets and women sandles to sell

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy more fish to sell

loans.name: Romanita

texts.en:
Romanita C. is from the town of Trinidad. She is married and has 4 school-aged children. Romanita owns and operates a general store where she sells a variety of products in the local community. Romanita has been engaged in her business for over 20 years. A few months back, she invested in seaweed farming and she hopes this new venture to grow as well.

Romanita joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Romanita has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI. Romanita is requesting a new loan of 50000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding her seaweed farming business. This loan will be the fifth loan taken out by Romanita from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to make improvements to her house. 

“Asenso Loans are a new product offered by CEVI for clients showing strong performance in previous loans, and who need a larger loan in order to continue to develop.  CEVI recognises the importance of helping people out of poverty, as well as providing continuous support and training as these clients progress.  

CEVI aims to provide financial services, not only our poorest clients, but also to our developing clients who should be rewarded for the way in which they display promising business skills.  Please help us provide support for these clients”

loans.use: To invest in expanding her seaweed farming business

loans.name: Lazaro

texts.en:
Lazaro O. is from the town of Sta. Josefa. He is 46 years old and married. He is a hard-working father to 4 school-aged children. To make a living, Lazaro owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from planting and harvesting rice for sale. Lazaro dreams of having all his children finish college and have bright futures.

Lazaro joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Lazaro has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI. Lazaro is requesting a new loan of 8000 PHP which will be used to purchase general farm supplies & equipment. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees of his children and improve their living conditions.

loans.use: to purchase general farm supplies & equipment

loans.name: Nemu-Nyaeh Group

texts.en:
Irene J., who is holding the sign, is the leader of this group of five borrowers called 'Nemu-nyaeh'.  She is 37 years old, married, and has four children whose ages are between four and fifteen years. She was only able to attend school through ninth grade due to lack of financial support. She cares for one sibling.

For thirteen years, she has been selling charcoal on Rehab Road, Paynesville on the outskirts of Monrovia, Liberia. She plans to use her 6,000 Liberian Dollar portion of this 26,000 Liberian Dollar group loan to buy more bags of charcoal. 

She describes herself as a God-fearing woman whose dream is to improve her business and build a house.

loans.use: To buy more bags of charcoal

loans.name: Alba Yanira

texts.es: Alba Yanira V. D.  B. D. 38 años D. edad, resiD. en el pueblo D. San Juan Opico, en donD. resiD. junto a su esposo, quien es una persona muy responsable con su familia, y así mismo vive junto a cuatro hijos D. 17, 14, 9 y 7 años D. edad, quienes se dedican a estudiar gracias al enorme esfuerzo D. sus padres. Alba es una señora muy trabajadora quien siempre esta dispuesta a dar lo mejor D. si para brindarle lo mejor a su familia. Ella trabaja comercializando ropa para mujeres, hombres y niños, así mismo venD. zapatos y sandalias, productos los cuales comercializa en: Sitio GranD., Las granadillas y otros lugares D. Opico, los cuales son muy conocidos y que cuentan con una gran afluencia D. personas. Alba posee muchos clientes quienes incluso le hacen pedido D. ropa, es por esto que Alba desea contar con el dinero necesario para comprar toda la ropa y zapatos necesarios para invertir en el negocio y D. esta manera mejorar sus ventas, lo cual es su mayor prioridad.
texts.en: Alba Yanira V. D. B. is 38 years old and lives in the San Juan Opico town with her husband. She is a very responsible person and lives with her four children of 17, 14, 9 and 7 years of age who are going to school thanks to the huge efforts of their parents. Alba is a very hardworking woman who is always ready to give her best and give her all for her family. She works selling clothing for women, men and children as well as shoes and sandals that she sells in Sitio GranD., Las granadillas and other places of Opico that are very well known and have large crowds. Alba has many customers that ask for her clothing which is why Alba wants to have the money necessary to buy all of the clothing and shoes necessary to invest in the business and that will improve her sales, which is her main priority.

loans.use: To buy clothing and shoes to sell.

location.town: San Juan Opico, departamento de La Libertad

loans.name: Luzminda

texts.en:
Luzminda B. is from the village of Villa Verde, Balulang. She is 52 years old. Luzminda is separated from her spouse and has 4 adult children. She owns & operates a specialized retail store where she sells a variety of dried fish. She has been engaged in her business for over 11 years and earns approximately 8,000 PHP a month.

In 2010, Luzminda joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional dried fish to sell. Luzminda is requesting a new loan of 11,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory & provide working capital. This will be the 3rd loan taken out by Luzminda from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional inventory & provide working capital

location.town: Villa Verde, Balulang, Cagayan De Oro, Misamis Ori

loans.name: Sajana

texts.en:
This is 34 year-old Sajana D..  She is married and has 3 children aged 12, 10 and 8.  In 2008, she established her tea shop business.  Working 7 days a week and 8 hours a day, she supoorts her family.  She has already received, and successfully repaid, 2 loans from Patan BPW and used her most recent to buys food supplies for her shop.  In the future, Sajana plans to uplift the economic condition of her family.  She thanks you for your support. 

Whether on the streets of Kathmandu or in the villages outside of the capital, tea shops are places of business and meeting in Nepal.  Called a chiya pasal, these tea shops make a sweet, milky tea that can be purchased for a few cents a cup.  With a Kiva loan, BPW's borrowers are able to keep their store shelves stocked while increasing their profit margins by buying in greater volume. 

This loan was administered by Kiva's local partner MFI, Patan Business and Professional Women. Patan BPW became Kiva's first field partner in Nepal in 2007.  Patan BPW operates throughout the Kathmandu Valley, offering microcredit and business training programs to low-income women.  In addition to providing economic opportunity to their clients, Patan BPW seeks to empower Nepali women within the home and community.  For more information about Patan BPW, visit our partner page and keep an eye out for new loans and borrower updates:
 BPW Partner Page     Join our lending team: BPW Lending Team"

loans.use: to buy food supplies for her shop

loans.name: Fabiana

texts.es:
La socia pertenece al banco comunal  “LA AMISTAD DE OLLANTAYTAMBO ”;  El banco comunal está ubicado en el distrito de Ollantaytambo perteneciente a la provincia de Urubamba y departamento de Cusco.

La socia es la Sra. Fabiana; La socia tiene 51 años de edad, es casada y tiene 3 hijos, la socia se dedica a la administración de su tienda abarrotes, la socia desea invertir en la compra de productos de primera necesidad para implementar su tienda abarrotes, ella tiene su tienda en el primer piso de su vivienda y trabaja con el apoyo de sus hijos. La socia comprará fideos, leche, arroz, azúcar al por mayor. La socia solicita el préstamo para invertir en la compra de productos de primera necesidad.

La socia  agradece y valora el préstamo otorgado mediante este medio y del mismo modo se compromete en cumplir con el pago de sus cuotas en el plazo establecido.
texts.en:
The member belongs to the community bank "La Amistad de Ollantaytambo" which translates to "The Friendship of Ollantaytambo". The community bank is located in the Ollantaytambo district which belongs to the Urubamba province in the department of Cusco. 

The member's name is Fabiana. She is 51 years old, is married and has three children. Her business is managing her grocery store. She wants to invest in purchasing staples for her grocery store. She has her store in the first floor of her home and she works with the help of her children. She will buy pasta, milk and sugar wholesale. 

The member is thankful for and values the loan granted through this medium and agrees to comply with the payment terms.

loans.use: Invest in purchasing staples to sell at her grocery store.

loans.name: Grace

texts.en:
Grace O. is 24 years old and is from the Khisero area in Kakamega. She is married to Charles and they have a daughter who is 2 years old.

Grace is in the business of selling fabric that her clients buy to make nice outfits from. She normally stocks the African textiles known as “Kitenge”. She is applying for her first loan from KADET LTD after being introduced by a client. She will use the money to add more textiles to her inventory to enable her to meet the demands of her clients.

Her desire is to be able to open up a boutique in the future.

loans.use: To increase inventory

loans.name: Mrs. Mak Aun Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Mak A. is a village bank president who has been selected by nine members that made up a village bank loan group. They live in Roka Khpos village, Takeo province. 

She is a farmer who owns a one-hectare plot of land to grow potatoes and beans to sell to support her family. Her husband, Mr. Touch Hieng, is a palm juice collector who is able to earn some money from selling palm juice and palm sugar. She has some problem because her husband does not have enough equipment for collecting palm juice. So to improve this business, Mrs. Mak A. is requesting for a loan to buy some supplies for this purpose. She is a mother of three children, two of whom are attending in public school while the youngest one is six months.

loans.use: To buy palm juice collecting supplies.

loans.name: Claudia

texts.es: Claudia es socia del Banco Comunal Llamkasum, ella trabaja junto a su esposo preparando panes tradicionales de Ayacucho, los cuales vende en uno de los mercados principales. Claudia solicita su préstamo para la compra de productos para la elaboración de los panes como son harina y azúcar. Claudia dice que el negocio va bien ahora y como miembro de FINCA Perú, está aprendiendo a ser más puntual y responsable. Su sueño es tener su propia panadería.
texts.en:
Claudia is a member of the Llankasum Community Bank. She and her husband make the traditional bread of Ayacucho which they sell in one of the main markets. Claudia is seeking a loan to buy ingredients for the bread such as flour and sugar. 

She says that the business is doing well now, and as a member of FINCA Perú she is learning how to be more punctual and responsible. Her dream is to have a bakery of her own.

loans.use: to buy ingredients such as flour and sugar

loans.name: Peter

texts.en:
Peter is 50 years old married to Lucy C. who is also a business lady and this brings additional income to the family. they are blessed with six children.He does a coblar work whereby he repairs shoes,and he has been doing this for the last 22 years,and earns a monthly profit of KES. 22,000.

Peter has applied for his fourth loan from KADET LIMITED of Kshs 80,000 which he plans to use to materials for repairing shoes like threads, shoe glue e.t.c. He plans to buy a pick-up van with the anticipated profits which he will use to hire for transport business that he desires to venture into in the near future. 

He hopes to be able to support his family and the necessary basic needs.

loans.use: To buy assorted materials for repairing shoes e.g shoe glue,thread e.t.c

loans.name: Aracelis Del Carmen

texts.es: Aracelis del Carmen tiene 40 años, su actividad es la venta de mercadería en general. Hace más 11 años que tiene este negocio, inicio con muy pocos productos ya que no tenía suficientes ingresos para ofrecerles a sus clientes los productos que le solicitaban, pero con el paso del tiempo ha logrado obtener experiencia para atender a sus clientes. El financiamiento que solicita es para la compra de calzado, cosméticos, joyas entre otras cosas. Sueña con seguir adelante con este negocio y mantenerlo activo.
texts.en:
Aracelis del Carmen, age 40, sells general merchandise.  She has had this business for over 11 years.  She started with very few products because she did not have enough income to offer her customers the products they requested.

However, as time passed she managed to get experience in order to take care of her customers.

The requested loan is to buy footwear, cosmetics, and jewelry, among other things.  

She dreams of getting ahead in the business and keeping it active.

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Mukama Aliba Ayaggadde-Mukono Group

texts.en:
K. Persis is a 56-year-old mother of 8. She is happily married and has been in the charcoal sales business for the past decade in Nabuti-Mukono. Most households in Uganda, especially the low income ones, use charcoal to cook their meals.

Persis says she began this business to earn a living. Prior to establishing it, she was at her wits' end given that she was a housewife with no source of livelihood. The business now generates her 200,000 UGX monthly. She also has a rental business that brings her extra income. Persis, who belongs to Mukama Aliba Ayaggadde group, says she is going to use this loan to purchase more bags of charcoal to resell.

loans.use: to purchase more bags of charcoal

loans.name: Blanca Dayssi

texts.es:
Doña Blanca de 43 años de edad, reside en Usulután, tiene dos hijos con quienes vive y la casa donde residen es propia.  Ella es empleada de una comercial llamada Electrocentro y a la vez vende medicamentos, el trabajo lo posee hace 12 años y la venta hace 5 años.
Actualmente solicita un préstamo para comprar medicina y comprar materiales de construcción, pues los medicamentos que desea comprar son muy demandados y la vivienda pues solamente quiere mejorar algunos daños que esta presenta.
Esta inversión le ayudara a tener a disposición de los clientes, medicamentos nuevos para aliviar las enfermedades más comunes y frecuentes.
La aspiración de doña Blanca es ampliar el negocio y recibir ganancias que logren cubrir las necesidades del hogar.
texts.en:
Blanca, 43, lives in Usulután.   She has two children living with her in a house of her own.  She is an employee of a firm called Electocentro and she also sells medicine.  She’s had the job for 12 years and the medicine sales business for 5 years.

She needs the loan to buy medicine and building materials and supplies.  The medicine she needs to buy is very sought after and she also needs to do some home repairs.

This investment will help her have new medicine available for her customers to treat common, frequent illnesses.

Blanca’s goal is to expand the business and obtain profits to cover her household expenses

loans.use:
Part for building materials and supplies and part for medicineBlanca, 43, lives in Usulután.   She has two children living with her in a house of her own.  She is an employee of a firm called Electocentro and she also sells medicine.  She’s had the job for 12 years and the medicine sales business for 5 years.

She needs the loan to buy medicine and building materials and supplies.  The medicine she needs to buy is very sought after and she also needs to do some home repairs.

This investment will help her have new medicine available for her customers to treat common, frequent illnesses.

Blanca’s goal is to expand the business and obtain profits to cover her household expenses
.

loans.name: Alma

texts.en:
Alma M. is from the village of Abu, Baylao, Mambajao, Camiguin Province. She is 29 years old. Alma is married and has six school-aged children. To make a living, Alma owns & operates a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from buying & selling used clothing or "ukay-ukay" in the local community. She is also making and selling snacks like sweet potato & banana "cues". Alma has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 6000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2011, Alma joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Alma is requesting a loan of 4000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional ingredients like ripe bananas & sugar and as working capital. This will be the 1st loan taken out by Alma from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional ingredients like ripe bananas & sugar and as working capital.

loans.name: Benard

texts.en:
Benard is a dairy farmer from Litein town in the Rift Valley, Kenya, where he has been farming for 8 years. His farm produces milk which he sells to a local dairy plant and tea which he sells locally. 

He has requested a loan of 80,000 KES through Juhudi Kilimo to construct a zero-grazing unit (barn). The extra income from this loan will enable him to improve his family's livelihood. His biggest challenge has been poor weather conditions which affect his production. 

Benard is 37 years old and married with 3 children aged between 2 and 11 years. Two of the children are currently attending school.

loans.use: to construct a zero-grazing unit (barn)

loans.name: Annaliza

texts.en:
Annaliza A. is from the village of Hinaplanan, Claveria, Misamis Oriental. She is 33 years old. Annaliza is married and has four school-aged children. To make a living, she prepares and sells pork and chicken barbecue in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately $125 a month for these activities.

In 2011, Annaliza joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase raw ingredients needed, like meat and spices. This will be her 1st loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase raw ingredients needed, like meat and spices

loans.name: Chea

texts.en: Chea P., 48, is married and resides in Takeo province, Cambodia, an area known for Pre-angkorean temples. P. is a weaver, earning an income of about USD 2 each per day. Her husband is a farmer, earning an income of USD 1 per day. Each month, the family has to spend USD 45 on food and USD 45 on the other necessary expenses. P. is requesting a loan of USD 1200 to purchase more raw silk to expand her weaving business. This will be her third loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner.

loans.use: to buy more raw silk to produce silk products to resell.

loans.name: Lily Del Carmen

texts.es:
Lily, nació en la mina la India una comarca localizada en el departamento de León, es madre de tres hijos, de oficio comerciante. Comenzó con capital propio pues antes su esposo era el único que mantenía a su familia, pero después ella decidió tener su negocio propio su esposo la apoyo incluso fue el quien le ayudo con una pequeña cantidad de dinero y así empezó a comprar inventario para su venta de ropa y zapatos. Fue ofreciendo a sus vecinos mas cercanos, vendía en la calles, fue tocando puerta a puerta ofertando su mercadería con el tiempo fue adquiriendo clientela fija. Además ella posee una pequeña pulpería dentro de su casa que es su otro medio de subsistencia la cual tiende ella misma, sus hijos al ayudan a atender esta pequeña pulpería. 
Solicito  el crédito para comprar inventario nuevo como zapatos, camisas, pantalones. Considera una temporada buena para incrementar sus ventas ya se acerca el día de la madre y espera aumentar sus ventas, mejorar sus ingresos y abastecer su inventario.
Desea realizarle mejoras de infraestructura a su hogar  expandir su negocio, tener una tienda de ropa en su casa. Su meta próxima es ahorrar para poder pagarles una carrera universitaria a sus hijos ya que para ella son su mayor prioridad.
texts.en:
Lily was born in the mining district of La India, an area located in the department of León. She is a mother to 3 children and a business woman. Previously, her husband was the only breadwinner but then she decided to start her own business. She started it with her own capital, her husband also supported her and even gave her a small amount of money, so she began buying stocks of clothing and shoes to sell. She would offer to sell them to her nearest neighbours, she sold them in the streets, she went door to door selling her merchandise, and over time she acquired a regular client base. She also runs a small general store in her own home, her other source of income. She works here herself with the help of her sons.

She is applying for this loan to buy new stocks of shoes, shirts and trousers. She believes it is a good season for increasing her sales as Mother's Day is approaching. She hopes to increase her sales, improve her income and sell her stock. She wishes to carry out improvements to the infrastructure of her home, expand her business, and have a clothes shop in her home. Her next goal is to be able to save enough money to pay for her children to attend university as they are her biggest priority.

loans.use: She is applying for the loan to purchase new stock such as shoes, shirts and trousers.

loans.name: Narcizo

texts.es:
El señor Narcizo está casado con la señora Basilisa, con quien tiene 5 hijos todos mayores de edad.
Narcizo desde hace 30 años se dedica a la albañilería especialista en colocación de piedras.
Hoy en día ya tiene una buenísima cantidad de clientela formada y dos de sus hijos también trabajan con él para poder satisfacer a todos sus clientes con sus trabajos.
Con este crédito solicitado pretende comprar más piedras para que no pierda algún pedido de materiales debido a la demanda que recibe.
texts.en:
Narcizo is married to Basilia; they have five adult children.  Narcizo has been a bricklayer, specializing in stone installation, for 30 years.

Today he has quite a large established clientele and two of his sons work with him to meet all of his customer demand.

Due to the high demand he receives he intends to use the requested loan to buy more stones so that he won’t lose any possible orders he might get.

loans.use: to buy stone.

loans.name: Sainbayar

texts.en:
Sainbayar is 23 years old and lives with his wife and son in a ger, Mongolian yurt, in Uvs province of Mongolia. His son is 2 years old and goes to a kindergarten. 

Sainbayar manages a shoe making business, with the help of his wife in his town. They started their business at a rented workshop in 2008. His wife is responsible for making Mongolian traditional shoes and he is responsible for selling and repairing them. Now their business has been stabilized and they are planning to expand their business. He attributes their business success to the workshop's good location. Sainbayar has great enthusiasm and energy to continue their business in the future. He is a hardworking man who is going to renew his workshop soon. He says, "I want to have my own workshop someday." He is requesting a 700,000 MNT loan to purchase materials in order to make more shoes.

loans.use: to purchase materials.

loans.name: Mariam's Group

texts.en:
Mariam is 46 years old and operates a grocery store at her home to share the financial burden with her husband. Operating her business from her home also allows her to manage and perform her household responsibilities. 

Her husband is involved in selling buffalo milk. For that purpose, he has a buffalo at his home from which he gets milk every day that he sells to his community clients for a profit. He also has two goats and he will sell them to a butcher after raising them. 

Mariam is the mother of four children. All of them are enrolled in a local school and getting their education. 

She has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for the expansion of her grocery store business. With the loan, she will purchase groceries in bulk quantities which will allow her to fill the customers' orders and increase her profits. 

She has been operating this business for the past three years and hopes that the loan will help her improving her business further and increase her profits.

loans.use: To buy groceries for grocery store business.

loans.name: Violeta

texts.en:
Violeta is 60 years old and married. She has six children.

Violeta works hard to provide for her family. She runs a variety store in the Philippines. She has been running the store for four years and also earns an income from buying and selling rice. 

She has requested a PHP 15,000 loan through NWTF to purchase more stock to sell in her store.

Violeta has borrowed and repaid seven loans from NWTF before this loan. 

Violeta aspires to save enough to buy more farmland.

loans.use: to purchase more stock to sell in her store.

loans.name: Pen

texts.en:
Pen sells gasoline. Her husband repairs and washes motorbikes.  Their income is $8 per day.  She has 2 children, 8 and 1 year old.  Every month, she has to spend $60 on food, and $10 on other expenses. 

She would like a loan of $1200 to buy a motorbike and the tools for fixing the motorbike. Her husband's career is doing well because his many friends as a motor taxi driver have become his customers when they need to repair their motorbikes.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike and the tools for fixing the motorbike

loans.name: Ta-Kar-Su Group

texts.en:
In the photo are members of the “Ta-Kar-Su” group. They are small-scale entrepreneurs based in Makeni, a city in northern Sierra Leone. They are seeking a loan of 800,000 SLL for each member in the group. With this loan, they will be able to expand their businesses, make more profit, and consequently improve their standard of living. 

The leader of this group is Mohamedd. Mohamedd is 45 and was born in Makeni, where he is currently lives with his wife and child. His wife is a businesswoman and his child is attending secondary school. For 23 years now, Mohamedd has been selling used clothes. With his share of this loan, he is going to buy a bale of used clothes to add to his business.

loans.use: to buy a bale of used clothes to add to his business

loans.name: Djidiankola  Bougoula  I Group

texts.fr:
Les dix  membres du groupe DJIDIANKOLA BOUGOULA  I sont  des femmes mariées avec une moyenne d’âge de 41 ans et  en moyenne 6  enfants. Elles vivent la plupart dans les familles polygames à Kafla, l’un des villages de la commune rurale de Banco, préfecture de Dioïla, région de Koulikoro, 2ème région administrative du mali.
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de micro finance Soro Yiriwaso dans le but de pouvoir mieux organiser leurs activités en début d’hivernage. Les spéculations cultivées sont entre autres le riz et l’arachide. Elles sont à leur première collaboration avec l’institution.
Avec ce prêt,  MINATA, la  troisième debout, c'est-à-dire debout au milieu, compte acheter les intrants, les petits équipements et payer les frais de labour et de sarclage pour entretenir environs 1 hectare de riz et d’arachide.
Les productions sont vendues sur place au marché du village, au niveau du marché de Banco et de N’Golobougou, après les récoltes à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes. Elle compte réaliser un bénéfice de  100.000 F CFA en fin de campagne.
texts.en:
The ten members of the group DJIDIANKOLA BOUGOULA I are married women who average 41 years of age and six children each. The women live for the most part in polygamous families in Kafla, a village of the Rural Commune of Banco, Prefecture of Dioïla, Region of Koulikoro (2nd administrative region of the Republic of Mali). The group members are collaborating with the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso with the goal of better organizing their work at the start of the off-season. The crops grown include rice and peanuts. The group members are on their first collaboration with the institution.

With this loan, MINATA, who is the third one standing, that is, in the middle of the photo, intends to buy farm inputs and assorted supplies and equipment and to pay for plowing and weeding to maintain about one hectare of rice and peanuts. 

After the harvests, the produce is sold locally at the village market and at the markets of Banco and N’Golobougou. The customer base is composed of women and men. MINATA plans on making a profit of 100,000 francs CFA at the end of the planting season.

loans.use: to pay for plowing, seeds, fertilizer, herbicide, weeding and assorted supplies and equipment

loans.name: Ma. Catherine

texts.en: Ma. Catherine is married and has a coffee shop business in the Philippines. She has been in this business for seven years now. Ma. Catherine requested a 16,000 Philippine peso loan through NWTF to purchase additional stock of coffee to sell. Ma. Catherine works hard to support her family. In the future, Ma. Catherine would like to expand her business to secure the financial stability of her family.

loans.use: to purchase additional stock of coffee

loans.name: Juliet Helen

texts.en:
Juliet Helen is engaged in managing a variety store in her  village. She is now 47 years old and has two school-age children. Due to the high cost of commodities and school fees, she needs to earn more income to support her children's education and satisfy their basic necessities. 

Juliet Helen aims to improve her variety store to increase her income. Due to inadequate capital, she is asking for a loan of P10,000 to buy toothpaste, beverages, seasonings, bread, junk foods, noodles, candies, eggs and soft drinks to sell. She believes that this loan will help to increase her product offerings and income. 


At this time, Juliet Helen is striving hard to make the business grow so that it will become viable and profitable in the future.

loans.use: to buy toothpaste, beverages, seasonings, bread, junk food, noodles, candies, eggs and soft drinks to sell in the village

loans.name: Kadycha's Group

texts.en:
Kadycha is the treasurer of this group. She is 59 and together with her husband, who is a retiree, she brings up two daughters. Both of them are students. 

In order to earn money to support the family, she cultivates agricultural products and breeds livestock. Selling some part of the harvest and reselling animals after fattening, the family earns about 7,000 KGS per month. With the profits gained from these activities Kadycha purchased a tractor. 

She applied for the loan because she needs money to purchase more livestock for breeding. In the future Kadycha wants to see her daughters married.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---
This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused microfinance institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line: people (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only microfinance institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase livestock.

loans.name: Sarah

texts.en:
Sarah is 40 years old and married to David. She supports a family of ten people. She is a farmer who grows flowers and fruits. She has been doing this for a period of six years. 

She has applied for a loan of Ksh 20,000 which she will use to purchase irrigation pumps to enlarge the irrigated land. She earns an income of Ksh 4,000 per month.

The anticipated profit that she will make will be used to expand the farm. This is her first loan with KADET. Her hope for the future is for her farming activity to be successful and to supply fruits country-wide.

loans.use: to buy more irrigation pumps.

loans.name: Romelyn

texts.en:
Romelyn is 26 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married with one child. 

Romelyn has a shop that sells canned goods, snacks and beverages. She has had this business for five years.She requested a loan for 15,000 Philippines pesos (PHP) to buy canned goods, snacks and beverages.
 
Romelyn has been a member of HSPFI since 2010. In the future, Romelyn hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy canned goods, snacks and beverages.

loans.name: Monica

texts.en:
41-year-old Monica is a married woman with 3 children, aged 13, 11 and 7. Monica and her husband run a bakery. They work together to make bread and sell their products to the people in their community. This business has been running for 3 years. 

Monica has requested a loan to purchase flour, sugar, butter and other ingredients. Monica hopes for their business to grow bigger.

loans.use: buy baking ingredients

loans.name: Álvaro

texts.es:
El señor Álvaro tiene 32 años de edad, vive con su esposa.
El señor Álvaro, se dedica al comercio de ropa de vestir, junto con su esposa, ambos administran el negocio, tienen  más de 5 años de dedicarse ha esta actividad, la cual la aprendió de un familiar que se dedicaba al comercio de ropa. 

En la actualidad tiene disponible 10 docenas de prendas de vestir como: blusas para damas, camisas para caballero y ropa de bebe. El señor Álvaro antes de dedicarse a esta actividad, cultivaba maíz y frijol

Las compra de  la mercadería las realiza en un departamento de la zona oriental del país, que se encuentra ha 26 kilómetros del lugar donde él vive, en esta cuidad se pueden comprar la ropa ha precio cómodos para su comercialización y también donde él vive en el día del comercio que son los domingos, cuando llegan comerciantes de otras zonas ha vender ropa. 

Don Álvaro solicita un préstamo, a Fundación Campo para comprar: 6 docenas de blusas para damas, 6 docenas de faldas,  6 docenas de camisas para caballeros, 6 docenas de pantalones y  para bebe: pañales, mantillas cuturinas, calcetines, gorros, entre otros más.

Al comprar toda esta ropa contara con mercadería de moda y abastecerá la demanda que tiene en este momento, ya que él tiene un puesto de venta cerca del lugar donde esta el comercio informal de la ciudad. Por lo que tiene una gran demanda y a veces llegan a buscarle y él les dice que no tiene hasta la próxima semana.

 Realizando la inversión él podrá satisfacer la demanda existente y de esta manera venderá más y aumentara sus ingresos. Con estos ingresos, Álvaro comprara un local al interior del mercado municipal o  para alquilar un puesto para establecer su negocio y también desea hacerle mejoras a su vivienda como reparar las puertas y las ventanas de esta. Así mismo desea  adquirir vitrinas donde pueda mostrar sus prendas de vestir, adquiriendo mobiliario para establecer un mini bazar.
texts.en:
Alvaro is 32 years old and lives with his wife.   He and his wife are clothing merchants; they run the business together.  They’ve been in this line of work for over five years having learned from a family member who also was a clothes merchant. He currently has ten dozen articles of clothing like women’s blouses, men’s shirts and infant wear.  Alvaro used to be a corn and bean farmer before going into this business.

He buys his merchandise in a department in the east of the country that’s located 26 kilometers from where he lives.  Clothes to be sold can be bought there at affordable prices and also in his own town on market day, Sunday, when merchants from other zones come to sell clothes.

Alvaro asks Fundación Campo for a loan to buy six dozen women’s blouses, six dozen skirts, six dozen men’s shirts, six dozen pants and for infants: diapers, dresses, blankets, and caps, among others.

By purchasing all this clothing he will have stylish merchandise in stock and he will meet his current demand because he has a sales stand near where the city’s informal commerce takes place so demand is high and sometimes they come looking for something and he has to say that he won’t have it until the next week.

Making this investment will allow him to meet current demand and he will sell more and increase income.  With this income Alvaro will buy an inside stand in the municipal market or rent a stand to set up his business.  He will also do some home improvements like repair its doors and windows.  He also wants to acquire cases to display his clothing and acquire furniture to set up a mini store.

loans.use: to buy clothes.

loans.name: Aravoi Group

texts.es:
En la ciudad de Caacupé 12 mujeres, todas vecinas de esa ciudad, se unieron con el propósito de ayudarse las unas a las otras, para que por medio del trabajo en conjunto puedan ayudar a sus familias. Ellas se definen como mujeres trabajadoras y muy sacrificadas. Actualmente se encuentran en el segundo ciclo del programa de mujeres emprendedoras de la fundación paraguaya.
Una de las integrantes de este grupo es la señora Johana, quien se dedica a la venta de frutas, comenta que este trabajo la ha ayudado para mantener a su familia y también para mantener a su negocio mismo. Ella  trabaja mucho y una de sus metas es poder seguir creciendo y poder tener algún día u negocio grande donde pueda tener todo tipo de frutas. 
Ella solicita la ayuda para la compra de frutas de todo tipo, como ser bananas, naranjas, manzanas, sandias, melones y demás, los cuales siempre tienen salida.
texts.en:
There are 12 women from the city of Caacupé, all neighbors, who have joined together so that they could help one another. By working together, they will be able to help their families. They define themselves as hardworking and self-sacrificing women. They are currently participating in their second loan cycle with the Women Entrepreneurs Program of Fundación Paraguaya.

One of the group members is Sra. Johana, a fruit vendor. She says that her job helps her to maintain both her family and her business. Johana works long hours and one of her goals is to continue growing so that someday she will have a large business that sells all types of fruit.

She is requesting assistance so that she can buy all types of fruit such as bananas, oranges, apples, watermelons, melons, and other items because she always runs out of these products.

loans.use: to buy bananas, oranges, apples, watermelons, melons, and other fruits.

loans.name: Myriam

texts.es: Myriam de 56 años es una mujer emprendedora madre de un hijo de 21 años de edad, que vive en la ciudad de Barranquilla y se dedica a la fabricación de productos de fritanguera, pasteles, hayacas y productos derivados de la harina de trigo, además de la venta de refrescos y también de queso.  Desde hace 30 años, su madre viajó a Venezuela, país fronterizo con Colombia, y le dejó una tienda en la que Myriam puso su primera venta de avena y pan, posteriormente cambió esta actividad por la de fabricación de fritos, actividad que ha conservado durante sus cambios de residencia y con la cual ha logrado salir adelante con su familia.  Myriam sabe hacer de todo un poco en el área de culinaria, porque también ha tenido negocio de restaurante, e ha ido bien pero cuando se tiene que mudar empieza nuevamente la venta de fritos.  En esta actividad la ayuda su hermana, distribuyen en tiendas y  a la comunidad de su barrio al detalle. Sus compras las hace de contado en pequeñas cantidades y su sueño de crecimiento, está basado en adecuar una buena infraestructura para mostrar sus productos y ofrecer un ambiente confortable a sus clientes.  Esta es la razón por la cual acude a su credikiva, primer financiamiento que hace a la Fundación Mario Santo Domingo, con el cual comprará  una vitrina,  un peso para pesar el queso, mesas y sillas para agregar almuerzos, como un nuevo producto que últimamente ha pedido su mercado, pues conocen la sazón con que en este negocio se cocina. Su sueño más adelante es tener su casa propia y sobre todo crecer como empresaria y como negociante, teniendo el capital de trabajo suficiente para mantener a su clientela como  a ella le gusta: satisfecha.
texts.en:
Myriam, 56, is an enterprising woman and mother of a 21-year-old son.  She lives in the city of Barranquilla and works making fried fast food items, cakes, ‘hayacas’ [type of tamale] and other products derived from wheat flour; she also sells soft-drinks and cheese.  

Thirty years ago her mother moved to Venezuela, a country bordering Colombia, and left Myriam a store where she started her first business selling oatmeal and bread.  She later changed this business for the one making fried fast food items, an activity she’s kept throughout her changes in residence and with which she’s managed to get ahead with her family.  

Myriam knows how to do a little of everything related to cooking because she’s also owned a restaurant.  She’s done well but every time she has to move she falls back on making fried fast food.  Her sister helps her in this activity; they sell to local stores and to her neighborhood community at retail.  She buys in small amounts and pays cash and her dream for growth is based on installing improved infrastructure to display her products and provide a comfortable environment for her customers.  

This is the reason she’s calling on Fundación Mario Santo Domingo to request her first Kiva loan to buy a display case, a scale to weigh the cheese and tables and chairs to start serving lunches as a new product her market is asking for because they know the tasty way she cooks.  Her dream for later on is to own her house and, above, all, to grow as a businesswoman and merchant having sufficient working capital to keep her customers the way she likes to: satisfied.

loans.use: to buy a display case, a scale to weight the cheese, tables and chairs to add lunches.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to add a room.

loans.name: Nasibali

texts.ru: Насибали проживает в районе Джиликул. Возраст, 43 года. Женат. Имеет четверых детей. Его жена и брат работают в дехканском хозяйстве. Сам он занимается выращиванием овощей. В этой области он более 20 лет. Кредит берет для посева пшеницы.
texts.en: Nasibali lives in the Jilikul district.  He is 43 years old, married and has four children.  His wife and brother work at a dekhan farm.  Nasibali is involved in growing vegetables.  He has been in this business for over 20 years.  He is requesting this loan for sowing wheat.

loans.use: to sow wheat

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy flour, eggs, butter and other products.

loans.name: Hilda

texts.es:
La socia Hilda pertenece al banco comunal "MAMACHA ASUNTA DE CALCA"; El banco se encuentra ubicado en la provincia de Calca perteneciente al departamento de Cusco, a una hora de la ciudad del Cusco.

La socia tiene 33 años de edad y es casada, la socia tiene 1 hijo de 6 años de edad; la socia se dedica  la compra y venta de productos deprimera necesidad porque tiene su tienda de abarrotes en su domicilio y ella implementa su negocio cada quincena; la socia solicita el prestamo para invertir en la compra de productos de primera necesidad, la socia comprara arroz, azucar, leche, fideos.

La socia agradece el préstamo y se compromete a cumplir con el pago de sus cuotas en el tiempo establecido.
texts.en:
Hilda is a member of the Mamacha Asunta de Calca communal bank in Calca province, Cusco department, an hour from Cusco.

She is 33, married and has a 6-year old son.  She buys and sells staple goods because she has a general store in her home and she sets up her business every two weeks.  Hilda is requesting a loan to buy basic products such as rice, sugar, milk and pasta.

This member appreciates the loan and promises to be punctual with her payments in the established time period.

loans.use: to buy staple goods such as rice, sugar, milk and pasta

loans.name: Jorgie

texts.en:
Jorgie is 30 years old and lives in Calaran, Calamba. She is married with 2 children.

Jorgie has a grocery store business and earns approximately 4,600 PHP each month doing this type of work. She has requested a loan of 50,000 PHP to construct her own house. 

Jorgie has been a member of PMPC for 4 years.

loans.use: to purchase 30 bags of cement, 40 pieces of galvanized iron sheets, etc. to construct her own house

loans.name: Susan

texts.en:
Susan is a single mother of two and she is aged 53 years. She is a retired clinical officer and an active member of Konguini Jisaidie. The group has been working with WEEC for the last four years. Since she joined the group for years ago, she has borrowed four loans and paid very well. 
Susan started her business in 2003; she sells new clothes which she buys from Nairobi and some from Tanzania such as Vitenge. Currently, her business is worth USD1200 and it continues to grow. Her average sales range from USD300-500 per month. This is a season for those who sell clothes because all farmers have finished harvesting and are now selling. Also, Christmas is around the corner and some people shop early not to be over charged in December.

loans.use: Susan wants to buy dresses, skirts, blouses and shirts for men such that she does not experience stock outs.

loans.name: Fasialofa

texts.en: Fasialofa’s business is making German Buns (fried dough with coconut shavings in the middle) which she delivers to village schools and shops. With 6 children to look after (3 attending school,1 who works and 2 others still at home), Fasialofa has to work extra hard to help her husband who's the breadwinner of the family. Her husband’s earnings don't cover their expenses, so Fasialofa makes and sells German buns to help satisfy their daily necessities. She makes a profit of 120 tala (US$ 40) per week after all expenses. Now she’s able to budget and still save some in case of emergencies. She‘s looking at expanding her business into a bakery. Hopefully one day she will be financially independent and able to manage things on her own.

loans.use: Purchase of new kerosene stove, Flour, Sugar, Coconuts, Oil, Cooking Pot, Frying  Pan

loans.name: Losivale Palepa

texts.en: Even though Losivale is getting old, she is still an active and hard working woman with 11 children. She started with a $750 loan to start her business of sewing and also printing materials. She used that loan to buy material, paints, thread and a brand new sewing machine to replace her old machine. She's interested in doing this business because she's very good at it, plus this is the business which helps her most with her children's education and food expenses. So, she is planning to get another loan with the hope of building a special house in which to operate and sell her finished goods.

loans.use: To purchase building materials

loans.name: Larisa

texts.en: Larisa supports herself and her high-school age daughter with her small market business selling a variety of electrical goods and appliances. During the five years she's been in business, she has developed a great mix of products and a solid customer base. Her kiosk is popular with customers because she is able to sell at lower prices than some of the larger electronics stores. Larisa originally got involved in her own business at the encouragement of her sister. Her sister and brother-in-law continue to help her with the business. Eventually they would like to open larger sales location together. Larisa and her daughter live with her mother in her hostel and are able to help with her mother's expenses as well. Larisa is requesting a loan for $1200 to purchase a supply of cell phone accessories. These popular items will sell well and bring in additional income through the summer season.

loans.use: To purchase inventory of cell phone accessories

loans.name: Epifania

texts.es:
TRANSLATED BY MATT FLANNERY

Epifania is 47 years old, is dedicated to the kitchen, happily married to Pablo Joaquin Carmona of 51 years who is assistant of mechanics in a great transport company in the city. They live in the District Apua Valley a district on Asuncio'n. They have 7 children, the oldest daughter is the one who helps with the making and sale of their products and the other children are very young.

Epifania makes each afternoon the Paraguayan soup (a typical food of the country done with flour of maize, cheese and milk), biscochos and cakes by orders. Her oldest daughter is the one in charge of the sales and she does crossing the streets, arriving house by house offering his products which very are accepted by the inhabitants of the zone. This office learned it of its mother from small and Mrs. Epifania teaches all to her daughters the secrets of her kitchen. 

The lady wishes to use the loan to buy ingredients like: flour, butter, milk, cheeses, eggs, sugar, and candies, stop of this form to increase the demand of sales and thus to obtain a greater margin of profit the lady belongs to the Group "Kuña Katypyry" of the Program Group of Enterprising Women that consists of 16 women who share in common work.

ORIGINAL SPANISH
Epifania tiene 47 años, se dedica a la cocina y repostería, está felizmente casada con Pablo Joaquín Carmona de 51 años quien es ayudante de mecánica en una empresa grande de transporte de la ciudad. Viven en el Barrio Valle Apua  un barrio de Asunción. Tienen 7 hijos, la mayor de sus hijas es quien la ayuda con la elaboración y venta de sus productos y los demás hijos son menores de edad.
Epifania elabora por las tardes la sopa paraguaya (una comida típica del país hecha a base de harina de maíz, queso y leche), biscochos y tortas por pedidos. Su hija mayor es la encargada de las ventas y lo hace recorriendo  las calles, llegando casa por casa ofreciendo sus productos los cuales son muy aceptados por los habitantes de la zona. Dicho oficio lo aprendió de su madre desde pequeña y la señora Epifania enseña a todas sus hijas los secretos de su cocina.
La señora desea utilizar el crédito para comprar ingredientes como: harina, manteca, leche, quesos, huevos, azúcar, y dulces, para de esta forma aumentar la demanda de ventas y así lograr un mayor margen de utilidad
La señora pertenece al Comité “Kuña Katypyry” del Programa Comité de Mujeres Emprendedoras que consta de 16 mujeres que conformar un grupo solidario de trabajo.

loans.use: para comprar harina, manteca, leche, quesos, huevos, azúcar, y dulces

loans.name: Lilia

texts.es:
For the last ten years, Lilia has been selling charcoal. She is the mother of four children, the oldest of which works outside the family sphere, and the other three are in school. She lives with her husband, who purchases and resells local fruit, such as the aguaje and the ungurahui, to clients such as local ice cream stores. The two are thoroughly immersed in their jobs, trying to bring comfort and well being to each member of their family. They rely on a stand that is strategically located on a corner to offer their products from very early in the morning until six at night. Additionally, their patio serves as a store for them to decrease costs and send that money to increase the quality of life for their family. Currently, the demand has grown such that they find themselves needing to increase their capacity to keep up with the demands of their clients. With the increase in capital, they will earn more income for the benefit and health of their beloved children. Let's make this Peruvian family's search for unity and continued improvement possible.

Translated from Spanish by Shannon Skoglund, Kiva volunteer

Lilia se desempeña vendiendo carbón desde hace diez años, es madre de 4 hijos de los cuales el mayor trabaja y está fuera del cobijo familiar, los otros tres están en la escuela y vive con su esposo que trabaja comprando y revendiendo frutos regionales como el aguaje y el ungurahui teniendo como principales clientes a las heladerías de su localidad. De esta manera los dos están inmersos en la labor de brindarles bienestar a cada uno de los miembros de su familia. Cuentan con un puesto ubicado estratégicamente en una esquina, en el que ofertan sus productos desde muy temprano hasta las 6 de la tarde, además tienen un local en el patio de su casa que les sirve como almacén para abaratar los costos y destinar ese dinero para incrementar la calidad de vida de su familia. Actualmente debido a que la demanda se ha acrecentado se encuentran en la necesidad de aumentar su capacidad de compra para poder seguir cumpliendo con su exigente cartera de clientes. Así mismo con el incremento de su capital generará mayores ganancias para beneficio y bienestar de sus queridos hijos. Hagamos posible esta petición para que esta familia pucallpina pueda seguir unida y en continua mejora.

loans.use: Purchase and supply of charcoal to increase sales

loans.name: Luisa Magina Bonilla

texts.en:
Luisa is an honest and happy mother who sells women’s shoes and slippers. Her stall is located in a crowded public place in the region of Yamasá. Her three boys and one girl attend school.

Luisa started her business almost two years ago and says that she has learned the rules of the market and she has gained the ability to make her business progress. Currently, she has a lot of customers who are very satisfied with the quality of the products and the personalized service she offers each of them.

The entrepreneur thinks that December is a very suitable moment to make things happen. She wants to purchase goods from the wholesale market so that she can sell them at inexpensive prices and attract new customers and hold them. Luisa says that for that occasion she will also buy men’s shoes in order to offer a larger variety of products to the customers.

In the past, Luisa has proved to be a punctual and truthful person. She has already taken a loan from FSMA which she reimbursed without difficulty.

loans.use: Purchase of women's shoes and slippers to supply her business

loans.name: Benito

texts.es:
Mr.P. started his mattress business 12 years ago. As the business grew he was able to afford specialized equipment to improve the quality of his goods and services.
